Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Global Observational Constraints on Oceanic Response to Wind Forcing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The physical processes responsible for distributing momentum throughout the ocean surface boundary layer are the subject of active concern in the oceanographic community. This interest is motivated to a large degree by the central importance of correctly parameterizing upper-ocean processes in coupled climate models. At the same time, there is a tradition in oceanography of seeking physical information by examining the nature of the relationship between wind stress and observed surface currents. This study will contribute to a better understanding of the mixing processes that are needed to accurately parameterize the ocean surface boundary layer in global climate models, an important societal benefit. Any improvement in the ability to estimate surface currents given the wind forcing is expected to be of interest for oil spill response and other practical applications. A key output for the community will be an improved estimate of the locally wind-driven currents, which will be distributed from the Global Drifter Program's website as a supplementary data product. This project will also support an early-career scientist.

The goal of this project is to better understand the dynamics of the ocean surface boundary layer through the first global study of the wind/current transfer function. This is to be accomplished by analyzing in detail the response to wind forcing in the global array of surface drifters, which sample the ocean currents in the vicinity of their 15 m drogue depth. The global analysis is to be informed and tested by (i) a prototype study from the Salinity Processes in the Upper Ocean Regional Study region, near a well-instrumented air-sea flux mooring, and (ii) analysis of synthetic data generated with a recently improved turbulence closure model that explicitly includes Langmuir turbulence. The hypotheses that wind, wave, and stratification state substantially modify near-surface mixing will be tested by examining dependencies of the transfer function on various environmental parameters, such as Langmuir number. Observed patterns will then be interpreted and scrutinized by deriving new theoretical approximations to the expected transfer functions characterizing different mixing processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project has been to characterize and interpret on a global scale the spatially varying transfer function from the wind stress to the surface oceanic currents, principally using the data from surface drifters. The results aim at identifying and quantifying mixing and turbulent processes near the ocean surface, and at devising a predicting tool for wind-driven currents.

One focus of the UW component of this collaboration has been developing new modeling techniques, mixing schemes and analytical approaches to account for the physics of Langmuir turbulence due to surface waves, and for the excitation, downward propagation and lateral dispersion of near-inertial waves, in process models, scaling relations and turbulence parameterizations that predict the current response and wind transfer function in the upper ocean. Recently developed turbulence second moment closure (SMC) schemes for representing Langmuir turbulence (LT) in upper ocean mixing schemes have been improved to make them more stable, particularly under conditions of strong wave forcing. The scaling of turbulence kinetic energy (TKE) in this model, and its agreement with observed mixed layer vertical TKE from Lagrangian drifters has led to a better understanding of the scaling of energy and length scale in the surface layer, a development currently being applied to clarifying how atmospheric boundary layer Monin-Obukhov scaling of near-surface shear and tracer gradients are altered in the near-surface ocean by LT. A newer extension of the SMC of LT model to include nonlocal mixing effects consistently within the turbulence closure has been applied to the nonlocal vertical flux of momentum by LT, in addition to an added local flux down the vertical gradient of surface wave Stokes drift. An approach to include more of the physical evolution involved in the generation, downward propagation and lateral dispersion of near-inertial waves has been applied to ocean mixing process models to compare with the representation of the inertial current response in drifter observations and in the wind transfer function.

Another focus of the UW component of this collaboration has been supporting the lead PI and additional collaborators to understand and apply existing developments in our understanding of the effects of Langmuir turbulence and near-inertial waves on current and shear in the upper ocean and their impacts on the transfer function. This cooperative effort has included providing model code and guidance for the second moment closure model of LT and the additional process model for the representation of internal wave propagation in the evolution of near-inertial upper ocean currents and their representation in the wind transfer function. Further collaboration closely related to using simulations to accurately represent the wind transfer function has included implementation of an improved representation of surface wave Stokes drift in the COAWST coupled modeling framework, passing a more complete description of the Stokes spectrum from the SWAN wave model to the ROMS ocean model.

These individual and collaborative efforts have led to one accepted publication and another submitted for the UW component, as well as several conference presentations and participation in local outreach events, including the Pacific Science Center?s Climate Days. Analytical parameterizations of TKE and eddy viscosity in the surface layer that were developed in part through this project are being used in the current research of a graduate student at UW.
